body: Does this ever happen without cache? Your mention of switching between branches suggests some relationship with cache, and it's important to know whether "clean" run without cache is prone to this.

I suspect the `astmerge` in the `dmypy` server triggers this error, because `OverloadedFuncDef.setter` is defined as a `@property`.

From the error logs above we can see that the `AssertionError` is triggered during an `hasattr` call. Searching the codebase for an interesting `hasattr`, we find a `hasattr` call in [`replace_object_state`](https://github.com/python/mypy/blob/master/mypy/util.py#L400-L403). This results in possibly calling `hasattr` on `OverloadedFuncDef.setter`, which evaluates the property unconditionally (since `hasattr` is implemented using `getattr` [[1]](https://docs.python.org/3/library/functions.html#hasattr)), triggering the `assert` on [`mypy/nodes.py:615`](https://github.com/python/mypy/blob/v1.16.1/mypy/nodes.py#L615).

Main uses of `replace_object_state` are in [`mypy/server/astmerge.py`](https://github.com/python/mypy/blob/v1.16.1/mypy/server/astmerge.py).

Assuming the above I tried to create a reproducer. Which indeed made it reproducable:

```console
$ mkdir /tmp/hello
$ cd /tmp/hello
$ uv init
$ uv add mypy==1.16.1
$ cat >test.py <<EOL
from typing import Literal, overload

@overload
def a(x: Literal[1]) -> int: ...

@overload
def a(x: Literal["a"]) -> str: ...

@overload
def a(x: Literal["b"]) -> str: ...

def a(x: Literal[1, "a", "b"]) -> int | str:
    return x
EOL
$ uv run dmypy run test.py
Daemon started
Success: no issues found in 1 source file
$ cat >test.py <<EOL
from typing import Literal, overload

@overload
def a(x: Literal[1]) -> int: ...

@overload
def a(x: Literal["a"]) -> str: ...

def a(x: Literal[1, "a"]) -> int | str:
    return x
EOL
$ uv run dmypy run test.py
Exception ignored in PyObject_HasAttr(); consider using PyObject_HasAttrWithError(), PyObject_GetOptionalAttr() or PyObject_GetAttr():
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "mypy/nodes.py", line 615, in setter
AssertionError: 
Exception ignored in PyObject_HasAttr(); consider using PyObject_HasAttrWithError(), PyObject_GetOptionalAttr() or PyObject_GetAttr():
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "mypy/nodes.py", line 615, in setter
AssertionError: 
Exception ignored in PyObject_HasAttr(); consider using PyObject_HasAttrWithError(), PyObject_GetOptionalAttr() or PyObject_GetAttr():
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "mypy/nodes.py", line 615, in setter
AssertionError: 
Exception ignored in PyObject_HasAttr(); consider using PyObject_HasAttrWithError(), PyObject_GetOptionalAttr() or PyObject_GetAttr():
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "mypy/nodes.py", line 615, in setter
AssertionError: 
Success: no issues found in 1 source file

$ ... cycling between the versions of `test.py` consistently reproduces the error.
```

We probably want `OverloadedFuncDef.setter` to not be a `@property`, s.t. it is not evaluated by `hasattr`? Or we should prevent it from being evaluated by accident in some other way.

Quite a tricky bug ;).

In addition, we might want to replace [the use of `PyObject_HasAttr` for implementing `hasattr` in `mypyc`](https://github.com/python/mypy/blob/2f7ba4e52685cb81abdac81dc71a2ffe13e4dae8/mypyc/primitives/generic_ops.py#L251) with an alternative that deals with errors better?

I suspect the current implementation doesn't have the same semantics as the interpreter?

```python
>>> class A:
...     @property
...     def fail(self) -> None:
...         assert False, "hi"
... 
... hasattr(A(), "fail")
... 
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<python-input-0>", line 6, in <module>
    hasattr(A(), "fail")
    ~~~~~~~^^^^^^^^^^^^^
  File "<python-input-0>", line 4, in fail
    assert False, "hi"
           ^^^^^
AssertionError: hi
```

Huh, we even have such warnings reported in CI (expand the "Test" step):

https://github.com/python/mypy/actions/runs/16208971103/job/45765332955?pr=19422

> Huh, we even have such warnings reported in CI (expand the "Test" step):
> 
> [python/mypy/actions/runs/16208971103/job/45765332955?pr=19422](https://github.com/python/mypy/actions/runs/16208971103/job/45765332955?pr=19422)

From there:

> mypy/test/testmerge.py: 2 warnings

That also confirms my suspicions around `astmerge` being the triggering factor. :)

It is probably a good idea to turn `PytestUnraisableExceptionWarning` (and possibly other warnings) into an error. There is `pytest`'s [`filterwarnings` ](https://docs.pytest.org/en/stable/how-to/capture-warnings.html#controlling-warnings) for that:

```toml
# pyproject.toml
[tool.pytest.ini_options]
filterwarnings = [
    "error::PytestUnraisableExceptionWarning",
]
```

Or even better:

```toml
# pyproject.toml
[tool.pytest.ini_options]
filterwarnings = [
    "error",
    # Add an ignore line for any warning you explicitly want to ignore.
]
```

Yeah, just global `error` would be better - IIRC there are no warnings we want to silence deliberately. I only noticed these warnings in CI yesterday by accident and didn't have time to open a ticket...
(for future readers: this is **not** a crash, exception is **logged** by dmypy, not raised, label "bug" is correct)

issue.title: Fix "ignored exception in `hasattr`" in dmypy
issue.body: Fixes #19425. That property has no setter so it should safe to exclude. It can raise in inconsistent state that arises when it is not copied last?

body: I've been running into this with dmypy as well
